fields.description:
There is already a setting to refuse merging from a pull request if the necessary number of required builds is not met (*ref.*:._Requires a minimum of  successful builds_ setting).  For our workflow this is not sufficient. We would really much like to accept a pull request only if the last commit in the pull request commits hierarchy (*HEAD*) is _green_. 

I would argue this is a more generic use case than having *X* random green builds from the pull request build.

*Or*, we misunderstood Stash completely and our repository configuration is wrong?!

*Bonus* : A retry button next to the build result icon.
Sometimes, the build fail for reasons not related to the commited changes (power outage, hardware failure, ...). It would be nice to have the option to resend the event triggering a build.
fields.summary: Add "Requires succesfull build on HEAD commit"  setting to pull request

fields.description:
Hey,

It would be very valuable to be able to add a system ssh access key on Stash level as a complement to Project and Repo level.

The main use case for this is that we have an external system accessing all our created repos for configuration verification and for each new project created we need to remember to add the ssh key for the system. This is a manual task which is missed from time to time.
In this case it would have been great if I as the Stash system admin could have added this key on system level applicable to all projects/repos
fields.summary: Possibility to add ssh key on Stash level i.e. available to all Projects/Repos

fields.description:
Right now, Bamboo builds only appear as soon as they are finished (successful or failed). Sometimes, developers forget to check if the build is actually successful before they approve a pull request.

I would like to see builds appear as soon as they are queued, to remind everyone they should wait for the build to finish before approving the pull request.
fields.summary: Show Bamboo builds that are queued or in progress

fields.description:
At the moment, when pull request is opened, on details page of the pull request you see the result of the build for the head of source branch.
Unfortunately it doesn't show you the build status for codebase after pull request is merged even though, internally Stash keeps the references to pull request merge.

There is a plugin for it (https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.bolyuba.stash.plugin.stash-build-status-plugin) but it won't work with Stash-Bamboo integration and still requires custom status report of the build result.

It would be nice to:
1. Allow bamboo to build from successful result of pull request internal branch
2. Report this to pull request to person who is about to merge it can see how the build will look like.

Regards,
Alex Krupnov
fields.summary: Show build status for successful pull request merge result

fields.description:
Issue: 
stash git daemon over git+ssh protocol does not close connection on wrong protocol (by client).

Reproducing: 
curl -v http://your_stash_host:7999/your/stash/repo

Long description:
'go get <repo_url>' tries to pull the source code from remote SCM (git, svn, hg, etc) - see http://golang.org/cmd/go/#hdr-Remote_import_paths and 'go get' command description on the same page.

'go get' fails with git+ssh link. The reason is that 'go get' command tries to guess the protocol for the repository access, and goes in the following order: git, https, http, git+ssh. 

When it tries to guess the protocol, it simply runs 'git ls-remote <scheme>://repo-url'. So in case of Stash repo with git+ssh access, 'go get' will try:
#1 git ls-remote git://repo-url
#2 git ls-remote https://repo-url
#3 git ls-remote http://repo-url
#4 git ls-remote git+ssh://repo-url

#1 and #2 fail, and #3 gets stuck, so #4 never executes.
If I try #3 with curl, it never finishes indeed:

SFOLSASHAKMAC01: alexkr$ curl -v http://stash1.ops.****.com:7999/skras/httpstore.git
* Adding handle: conn: 0x7f8269801a00
* Adding handle: send: 0
* Adding handle: recv: 0
* Curl_addHandleToPipeline: length: 1
* - Conn 0 (0x7f8269801a00) send_pipe: 1, recv_pipe: 0
* About to connect() to stash1.ops.*****.com port 7999 (#0)
*   Trying 10.22.15.54...
* Connected to stash1.ops.*****.com (10.22.15.54) port 7999 (#0)
> GET /skras/httpstore.git HTTP/1.1
> User-Agent: curl/7.30.0
> Host: stash1.ops.****.com:7999
> Accept: */*
> 
SSH-2.0-SSHD-CORE-0.9.0-ATLASSIAN-5
^C
SFOLSASHAKMAC01:alexkr$ 


If I try the same to the local SSH port (listening by sshd), curl reports protocol mismatch and connection is immediately terminated by peer (sshd):

root@g2mgdev1app1:~# curl -v http://localhost:22/
* Hostname was NOT found in DNS cache
*   Trying 127.0.0.1...
* Connected to localhost (127.0.0.1) port 22 (#0)
> GET / HTTP/1.1
> User-Agent: curl/7.35.0
> Host: localhost:22
> Accept: */*
> 
SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_6.6.1p1 Ubuntu-2ubuntu2
Protocol mismatch.
* Recv failure: Connection reset by peer
* Closing connection 0
curl: (56) Recv failure: Connection reset by peer
root@g2mgdev1app1:~#
fields.summary: golang support: 'go get' fails to pull repository over ssh

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}


/dev/random blocks if the entropy pool is empty whereas /dev/urandom does not block. In most Linux distros /dev/urandom is always primed with 32 bytes either from the initial installation or from a hashed carryover from the previous boot which makes it unpredictable enough for non-information-theoretically secure algorithms.

See [http://security.stackexchange.com/a/7074]

This caused horrifically slow startup times for a customer's install (Tomcat's SecureRandom for session IDs was blocking for 6 minutes).
fields.summary: Consider forcing Stash to use /dev/urandom not /dev/random for SecureRandom seeds to avoid slow startup on low initial entropy systems

fields.description:
It would be great if Stash and Bamboo together could implement a gatekeeper-style strategy that actually prevents a direct push to the master branch, and instead defers the merge until a basic build and test have passed.

Currently, this is not possible as there is no way to prevent a user pushing to master branch in Stash without also preventing the Plan Build from merging to master as that same user.
fields.summary: Implement Jenkins/Gerrit style worflow to protect master branch from direct pushes.

fields.description:
Reproducing steps:

1. Create an Admin account and two Stash User account.
2. Admin account -> Create a repository and enable public access
3. Stash User A -> Fork Admin's Repository to Personal Repository
4. Push a commit into Stash User A repository
5. Create a PR from Stash User A personal repository into Admin User public repository with attachment, initiated by Stash User A
6. Login Stash User B and download the attachment. Error 401 is reproduced.

*This is also reproducible although Stash User A has assigned Stash User B as a reviewer
*This is also reproducible although the PR has been declined and re-opened
*In this case, other users who has Admin Privilege and above can have access the attachment without throwing Error 401

The current workaround is to reattached the same file by editing the PR. (While editing, you must remove the entire attachment line and re-attach the same file back)
fields.summary: The attached file in pull request cannot be accessed (Permission Denied) by other Stash Users

fields.description:
Rekeying is meant to happen after 1G of data transferred or 1 hour of connectivity. MINA 0.9.0 does not correctly handle rekeying. There is code that purports to support it but it fails in practice. Work has been done in more recent versions of MINA to both better support client-initiated rekeying (which the server cannot ignore) and to add basic support for server-initiated rekeying. We should upgrade.

To reproduce, in ~/.ssh/config add the following and attempt to clone using SSH:
{code}
Host stashhost
   LogLevel DEBUG3
   RekeyLimit 1K
{code}

{code}
git clone ssh://git@stashhost:7999/stash/stash.git

Provide an option to disable the PR link in git console output on a per repo basis

fields.description:
Rather than always showing the create PR link in the console output of git push, it would be good to apply some smarts to it. 

Excluding the link from being shown when the current branch is the repository default branch, or when it is indicated as the "development", "production", or a "release" branch might be a good option.
fields.summary: Selectively show the create PR link in the git console output based on the branch model

fields.description:
Our developers think it is inconvenient that the links from JIRA to Stash opens in the same window as their JIRA issue. So after they've clicked on a Stash link and went to view a branch in Stash, they want to continue working on the issue, but the issue is no longer open in the browser.

*Reproduction*
1. Open a JIRA issue
2. Under Development click on 'branch' (or any other link)
Now a pop-up opens to show the details
3. Click on any link, e.g. the Branch
This opens Stash, the JIRA issue is now gone.

*Desired*
They'd like to continue working on both JIRA and Stash at the same time, therefore it would be easier if the Stash link opened in a new window.

*Workaround*
I have suggested the use of <ctrl>+leftclick or middleclick to open the link in a new tab/window. 

This slightly relates to the issue JRA-9380.
fields.summary: Links from JIRA to Stash should open in new window

fields.description:
If you go to the Branching Model page for a repository with default settings, and deselect the Release branch checkbox then "Enable automatic merging" becomes disabled as expected (as neither condition for auto-merging is met). 

However if you now select a Production branch the "Enable automatic merging" checkbox remains disabled, even though it should be enabled in this state.

You can get it back by toggling the Release checkbox on and back off again.
fields.summary: Branching model UI bug - auto-merge toggle can incorrectly be in disabled state

fields.description:
Different pull requests require different levels of approval.  The global "minimum approvals" makes it difficult to achieve this for a large repository.

It would be ideal to be able to specify the set of approvers and the minimum number for each individual pull request.
fields.summary: Allow # approvals to be specified on pull request basis

fields.description:
Ideally the backup client should disable third party plugins before it initiates a backup and re-enable them after the backup is finished.

An idea would be setting UPM to safe mode before the backup and unsetting it afterwards.

We should also provide instructions in the [DIY backup if possible|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+Stash+DIY+Backup].

Customers can get around this issue ("One or more database connections were not closed within the allotted timeout") if they follow this KB: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Backup+client+fails+due+to+the+error:+One+or+more+database+connections+were+not+closed+within+the+allotted+timeout
fields.summary: Backup client should disable third party plugins before starting backup

fields.description:
The gravatars in the inbox load over http, even when Stash is configured with https.

Generally, if HTTPS is used, all resources should be loaded with HTTPS. It causes fewer browser warnings.
fields.summary: Inbox gravatar always loaded over http

fields.description:
Using Chrome Version 38.0.2125.111 m, I have observed the diff content within a pull request diff tab being incompletely drawn (or, maybe overdrawn with a white panel).

(See attachment)

However, on continual mouseover of the area in question, the remaining content is *eventually* drawn.

I did not have this problem on Stash 2.11.3 using the same Chrome version.

Colleagues on Chrome 33 and 35 did not have this problem on stash 3.4.0, so it appears to be specific to the combination of Chrome 38 and stash 3.4.0.

Its not clear to me whether this is something Atlassian or Google should solve :-)
fields.summary: Pull Requests Diff incompletely drawn (3.4.0 + Chrome 38)

fields.description:
Scenario:
- In master branch there is a class A
- We create a feature branch off of master
- In the feature branch we create **a new additional class B** which is almost the same as class A (structurally almost equal).
- Create a new pull request to merge-back the feature branch to master
- In the pull request's side-by-side diff we have an entry for new class B (as expected)
- However, the left side of the diff shows class A where we expected nothing to see because class B is entirely new.
fields.summary: Side by side diff for new java file sometimes diffs to an existing other java file

fields.description: Under MSSQL (at least - other DBs not yet tested) a deadlock is formed when trying to set a global user permission. Note: I needed to create multiple groups and add global group permissions first to trigger the deadlock.
fields.summary: Transactional deadlock when setting global user / group permissions

fields.description:
Scenario:
- The user registry contains 2 users u1 and u2 that have the same e-mail address.
- User u1 merged a pull request to master branch
- For the repo I selected to show the "Commits" (link on the left "bar")
- User u2 is shown for the "merge pull request..." commit.

Analysis:
- We changed the user registry so that there are no duplicate e-mail addresses anymore.
=> Now, the correct user u1 is shown for the "merge pull request..." commit.
fields.summary: "Commits" list for a repo sometimes credits wrong user

fields.description:
As part of changes for Stash Data Center, sessions now go through serialization and deserialization even in standalone Stash instances where it is not required.  Normally this is relatively inexpensive, but if sessions contain a large amount of data (for example, if custom plugins store additional information in the session), the costs can add up. 

We should optimize this so that session data avoids serialization and deserialization by default.
fields.summary: Optimization: Avoid serialization and deserialization of session data by default

fields.description: On the page https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/how-tos/responding-to-application-events.html the class that gets created is called {{MyStashEventListener}} however the {{atlassian-plugin.xml}} snippet refers to it as {{MyEventListener}}.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Every time the Bitbucket Backup Client it creates, together with the expected backup (in tar format), a zip in the {{BITBUCKET_HOME/export}} folder is created.
This file is not removed after the backup is generated and the size of the folder can grow indefinitely as more backups occur.

This file is temporary and can be safely removed after the backup completes.

h3. Suggested Solution
Limit the backup to a configurable time or count window or delete them after the backup has been successfully generated.

h3. Workaround
Implement a maintenance procedure to remove these files.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to limit the number of zip database backup files in the export directory

fields.description:
The {{stash-config.properties}} contains sensitive information like SQL credentials in plain text.  The contents of the file should not be world-readable.

Stash uses the default file permissions of the running user for all the files it creates. For a zip/tar.gz install of Stash it is up to the administrator to configure the run user correctly. However, the Linux installer automatically creates {{atlstash}} user.  The installer should ensure the {{stash-config.properties}} file is not world-readable.
fields.summary: Database migration should ensure stash-config.properties file permission is 0640

fields.description:
During merge from commit R into local commit L, with some merge-base B, if they refer to corresponding commits R' L' and B' in a submodule, and those are different, Git (and stash) will report a merge conflict. But, if the merge is performed in local reporitory, and the submodule is checked-out, git will inspect its history and check if L' is a ancestor of R'. If it is, it will fast-forward the submodule to R' without reporting conflict. It works since https://github.com/git/git/commit/68d03e4a6e44

If stash could perform this in server-side merges it would let go most of the conflicts complaints developers experience with submodules. One way to achieve it is to just have the submodules initialized in the server repository (it is possible to avoid prformance issues with use of alternate object storage and skip-worktree flag), but I'm not sure how will it affect other functionality, it can break something.
fields.summary: Support auto fast-forwarding submodules during merges by having submodule initialized

fields.description:
It would be nice to have the Tag/Branch name to be displayed for submodules together with the commit hash.

A repository in Stash with submodules display the commit hash in the following format:-
{{submodule_name @ xxxxxx}}. Clicking the submodules lists the related tag. It will be much easier if the information can be viewed without navigating and the details can be displayed in the following formats:-
{{submodule_name @ xxxxxx (Tag: xxxxx)}}.
{{submodule_name @ xxxxxx (Branch: xxxxxx)}}.
fields.summary: Display Tag/Branch Name For Submodules

fields.description:
Currently Stash allows you to specify a "Default Branch". This cannot be deleted and in gitflow makes sense to be `develop`.

In the branch configuration you can select a "Development Branch" (develop) and a "Production Branch" (master)

It would be nice to have the option to stop the production branch from being deleted.

Example use case:
1) hotfix created from `master`
2) auto-merge pushes to `develop` but fails, so puts in a pull request from master -> develop
3) user fixes conflict and merges in Stash, but forgets to uncheck the "Delete source branch" box (which has a setting to remember it's last value)
4) *`master` is auto-deleted from Stash.*

This seems to be a fairly easy workflow to be able to accidentally delete master and seems a tad risky to me! As long as someone has an up-to-date version of master on their machine they can push it up again, but what if they don't???
fields.summary: Disallow Deletion of "Production Branch"

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When accessing the diff for large pull requests via rest, the response can be truncated.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Access the pull request diff rest endpoint in a browser or using cURL - [https://stash.company.com/rest/api/1.0/projects/PROJECT/repos/repo/pull-requests/1804/diff]
 # Returned JSON data will be truncated

h3. Expected Results

Returned JSON response is not truncated and can be parsed
h3. Actual Results

JSON response is truncated.

In the browser, the response usually ends with:
{code:java}"createdDate":1412767342465,"updatedDate":1412767404799,"comments":[],"attributes":{},"tasks":[],"permittedOperations":{"deletable":false,"editable":false}}
{code}
With cURL, it can end more abruptly:
{code:java}...,"author":{"name":"user","emai{code}
h3. Workaround

If using curl, add {{--http1.0}} to the command.
fields.summary: pullrequests/diff rest call returns incomplete JSON response

fields.description:
We have a workflow where we pull request from a "develop" branch to a "release" branch for daily and weekly builds.  Infrequently, but often enough to be annoying, the tip of trip has an issue and we would like to create pull request from an earlier commit.  

Similarly, when there is a merge conflict, I would like to merge an earlier commit which would be "conflict free", then merge the conflicting commit and push for a code review.  This narrows the scope of the code review to the conflicting files.

Creating the branches for this can be done from the command line, but it would be more convenient if it was done in stash.

the index is -1 because the rules for cascading feature are not

I'm sure that such possibility would be appreciated by many users and system administrators.

fields.description:
The current default is

{noformat}
# Controls when caching is disabled because there is not enough space available on the file system
# Configured value is in BYTES. The default is 1GB
plugin.stash-scm-cache.minimum.free.space=1073741824
{noformat}

The minimum should be raised to at least 5GB to prevent the cache from filling up the disk for big repositories. For instance, if the disk only has 1.5GB free and a cache is written for a 2GB repository, the cache will go over the limit and caching will fail.
fields.summary: Increase the default minimum free disk space for scm-cache to prevent the disk from filling up

fields.description:
This does not present itself on HSQL. It has been reproduced on postgres 9.3.1, Stash 3.2.x.

Symptoms are some subset of repositories are missing and have been replaced by repositories already in the results when returning after the first page. The total number of records returned in equal to the number of visible repositories. Symptoms are present only when returning all repositories (ie not filtered by project).

See attached scripts for test data generation and API querying and analysis.

From the [postgres documentation|http://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.3/static/queries-limit.html] we have:

{quote}
The query optimizer takes LIMIT into account when generating query plans, so you are very likely to get different plans (yielding different row orders) depending on what you give for LIMIT and OFFSET. Thus, using different LIMIT/OFFSET values to select different subsets of a query result will give inconsistent results unless you enforce a predictable result ordering with ORDER BY. This is not a bug; it is an inherent consequence of the fact that SQL does not promise to deliver the results of a query in any particular order unless ORDER BY is used to constrain the order.
{quote}
HSQL likely survives by not having complex query planning.

The natural ordering is only on the {{name}} column so we have (effectively) unordered rows w.r.t. {{project_id}} It looks like we will need to update the ordering to be on {{name}} and {{project_id}}. We don't notice this in project repo lists since repos are constrained to unique names within a repository.
fields.summary: /rest/api/1.0/repos returning duplicate/missing results based on limit used

fields.description:

Is there an option (or future plans for one)?

fields.description: When the Branching Model performs an automated merge if conflict occurs an email is sent and a pull request is opened. Currently the email is sent to the pull request merger, and the new pull request is created with the original merger as owner.  The Stash Branching Model should offer the option to (also) email the pull request creator, and create the resulting pull request with the original PR creator as owner.
fields.summary: Branching Model: email/PR by creator

fields.description:
The {{start-stash.sh}} passes the {{-m}} flag to {{su}} which preserves environment variables. If the script is started by root, this can cause permission issues because the {{HOME}} environment variable is set to {{/root}} and the {{atlstash}} user does not have permission to set Git config options.

{code}...
    if [ "$PRGRUNMODE" == "true" ] ; then
        $sucmd -m $STASH_USER -c "$PRGDIR/catalina.sh run $@"
    else
        $sucmd -m $STASH_USER -c "$PRGDIR/startup.sh $@"
    fi
...{code}

Results in the following errors when run as root:

{code}warning: unable to access '/root/.config/git/config': Permission denied
warning: unable to access '/root/.gitconfig': Permission denied
warning: unable to access '/root/.config/git/config': Permission denied
warning: unable to access '/root/.gitconfig': Permission denied{code}
fields.summary: start-stash.sh script preserves environment variables with -m flag causing permission issues
